title: Worked fine when I was on KitKat
comment: After upgrading to Lollipop (CM12S OTA) on my OnePlus One  I decided to try this again and, oddly enough, I was just disconnected from my home network without a pop-up prompt asking if I wanted to trust it. Hitting the switches did nothing, clearing data, rebooting to no avail.

title: Great app.
comment: Excellent Wi-Fi security features. A must have app.

title: One major flaw
comment: Although this app keeps you from logging on to wi-fi spoofs, it also keeps you from logging on to wi-fi sources that you are actually trying to log on to  You try, it doesn't work, and then you have to find the screen .that allows you to permit the same wi-fi. The app should detect that you are consciously trying to log on to the particular wi-fi source and either let you on or pop up the permission screen.
I does what its suppose to do and more

title: Simple Security
comment: This is an app that must be used in addition to other security measures in order to be truly effective. It helps prevent unauthorized snooping on your device but twice so far it did not function properly. The issue needs attention immediately as it involves connecting to approved WiFi connections. In my case, the connections were my work and home routers, two very important connections. I'll monitor the issue and update my review when the reliability improves.

title: Seems like a good idea
comment: Updated for review of v2.0.  It now works great on my home network, but when Privacy Police is active, I cannot connect to my work WiFi.  This makes me think it's an issue with the work network settings.

Hi Allen! I'm sorry to hear that.

Could you provide me with a bit more information: is this for any network? What is the status line underneath the network you want to connect to in your Wi-Fi configuration screen? If you have any technical Android knowledge, a logcat would be very helpful. 

I will try to find a Note 3 to test on asap!

title: Purpose built
comment: It would be nice to have more technical debug information under the hood, right now you just rely on it working without knowing much else.

title: Perfect. [EDIT: Not...]
comment: EDIT: Buggy. Permanently disabled my wifi no matter what I do.  Phones should have this built in. The fact your phone is shouting "I always connect to THIS wifi network, are you this network? I want this network. Is it you?" is offensive. Any hacker or thief could track your home location(s) from your phone if you previously didn't disable wifi. If you forget to disable your wifi, or you just don't want to turn it off because you want wifi apps to work when you are in range automatically, then this app is for you. If you are into privacy and security as I am, then this app is for you. It will enhance your privacy and security by preventing you from connecting to fake networks that pretend to be your network and prevent people from finding all the places you connect to.  Get it, install it, be safe.

title: Very useful
comment: Great privacy app

title: Small and Fast
comment: This does exactly what it says. It's a small, lightweight app that can protect you from malicious WiFi signals.

title: Great idea
comment: Would be nice to have a list-editing feature tho. I sometimes accidentally press No...
Hi Gábor! The list-editing feature is now available in the latest version, let me know if you have any feedback :-)

Hi Darryl. Could you let me know in which cases the app doesn't work? I'd really like it to work for you 100% of the time :-)

title: Privacy Police app
comment: Beware of this app. It can stop your Wifi connection and uninstall updates. Do not download on Samsung Galaxy S4

Hi Paul. Could you give me a bit more information on what the problem on your phone is exactly? Other S4 users do not seem to have the connection dropping problem. Uninstalling updates should definitely not be happening as a result of installing PrivacyPolice; it does not even have the permission to do this. Please provide a logcat if possible

title: Why is this not default behavior??
comment: I've always been annoyed at the way Android will connect to any AP with a known SSID promiscuously. I had no idea just installing an app could turn that off.
Good

title: It works but.......
comment: It works like it should but after a few days it would not allow me to even manually turn on WiFi for some reason.  Uninstalled and my WiFi toggle is normal again.

title: Good app but battery hog
comment: Samsung Note 4: Good app, very useful but used a lot of battery power. Went from a full day+ before install to 1/2 day after install. Removed app and back to full day+ on battery life.

Hi Diego, I'm sorry to hear that; Wi-Fi PrivacyPolice shouldn't have any noticeable imact on your battery. If you have the time, could you try to re-install and confirm that PrivacyPolice is the problem when looking at your battery usage in your phone settings? If you know how to create a logcat, that would be of great help too.

title: Issues with HTC One M8 5.0
comment: I don't know if there are compatibility issues with the M8 running 5.0, but since installing I've had keyboard issues and tons of lag. Not sure if this is something that needs to be tested. Just wanted to give the heads up.

Hi Zach! That really shouldn't be caused by PrivacyPolice. If you have some technical experience using ADB, could you send a logcat to edm.developer@gmail.com? This would allow me to check whether there's any unusual activity coming from the PrivacyPolice app, possibly caused by a different scanning mechanism on the One M8.

I'm a what now? :-)
Great app, the data protection option should be enabled by default though

Thanks for your feedback! The reason I opted not to have this option on by default is b/c the network requests may be annoying to some users if they don't know where these notifications are coming from (and b/c the first protection measure should be sufficient for most people). Though if enough people want this on by default, I might reconsider.
